toolUseResult.originalFile:
# Changelog

All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.

The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/),
and this project adheres to [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html).

## [Unreleased]

### Added
- Initial charm implementation for SunGather
- Traefik ingress integration for external access to web interface
- Configuration options for inverter connection (host, port, connection type, scan interval)
- Support for multiple export destinations:
  - Built-in webserver (enabled by default on port 8080)
  - MQTT with Home Assistant discovery support
  - InfluxDB (versions 1.8 and 2.x)
  - PVOutput.org
- Juju secrets integration for secure credential management
- Three charm actions:
  - `run-once`: Execute a single data collection cycle
  - `get-inverter-info`: Retrieve inverter model and connection status
  - `test-connection`: Test connection to the inverter
- Ingress integration for external access to the web interface
- Smart meter support for household consumption calculation
- Configurable data collection levels (1=essential, 2=complete, 3=all registers)
- Configurable logging levels (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR)
- Comprehensive integration tests using Jubilant
- Comprehensive unit tests using ops.testing
- Mock Sungrow inverter server for integration testing
  - Implements Modbus TCP protocol with realistic register data using pymodbus 3.x
  - Implements HTTP/WebSocket protocol (WiNet-S simulation)
  - Supports both `modbus` and `http` connection types
  - Enables testing charm with working workload without hardware
  - Tests currently skipped (require working OCI image from rock/ directory)
  - See `tests/integration/mock_sungrow/README.md` and `TESTING.md` for details
- Working rock definition in `rock/` directory for building production-ready OCI images
  - Uses `uv` for fast dependency management (dependencies install in ~23ms)
  - Includes all 20 required Python packages (paho-mqtt, pymodbus, sungrowclient, influxdb-client, etc.)
  - Resolves ModuleNotFoundError present in default `bohdans/sungather:latest` image
  - Comprehensive build and deployment documentation in `rock/README.md`
- Documentation:
  - README with usage examples
  - TUTORIAL for step-by-step deployment guide
  - CONTRIBUTING for development guidelines
  - SECURITY for vulnerability reporting
  - Rock build instructions and troubleshooting guide

### Changed
- CI workflow now uses `uv` for faster test execution
- CI workflow uses Concierge for simplified Juju/K8s environment setup
- CI workflow now automatically builds and pushes rock to GitHub Container Registry
- Integration tests now use the newly built rock image from CI
- Integration tests clarified to verify charm robustness with broken workload images
- Error messages now include specific `juju config` commands for resolution
- Documentation updated with rock building and CI/CD information

### Fixed
- Charm filename reference in CI workflow (corrected to `sungather_amd64.charm`)
- Concierge installation in CI now uses `--classic` flag
- Rock build in CI now uses `--destructive-mode` to avoid LXD permission issues
- Rock build in CI now runs with sudo to avoid chown permission errors

[Unreleased]: https://github.com/canonical/sungather-operator/compare/HEAD...HEAD

lines: - Concierge installation in CI now uses `--classic` flag
- Rock build in CI now uses `--destructive-mode` to avoid LXD permission issues
- Rock build in CI now runs with sudo to avoid chown permission errors
+- Rock build in CI now runs on ubuntu-22.04 to match the rock base

content.thinking: Good! I've committed the fix. Now let me show a summary of what happened and wait for the user to push.

content.text:
Perfect! I've fixed the third CI issue. Here's what happened:

## Third Issue
The rock build failed with:
```
Ubuntu 22.04 builds cannot be performed on this Ubuntu 24.04 system.
```

The GitHub Actions runner was using `ubuntu-latest`, which is Ubuntu 24.04, but the rock is based on `ubuntu@22.04`. In destructive-mode, rockcraft requires building on the exact same Ubuntu version as the rock's base to ensure binary compatibility.

## Solution
Changed the runner from `ubuntu-latest` to `ubuntu-22.04` to match the rock's base.

## Changes Made
- Updated `.github/workflows/ci.yaml` to use `runs-on: ubuntu-22.04`

content.thinking:
The docker load succeeded, but the resulting image has `<none>:<none>` as the tag. This is because the rock image doesn't have a proper tag. I need to fix the way we're loading and tagging the image. Let me check the rock format better and adjust the workflow.

The issue is that when we load the Docker archive, it may not have repository:tag metadata. We need to tag the image by its sha256 ID instead of trying to get the repository:tag from the list.

The problem is that when the docker archive is loaded, the image doesn't have proper repository:tag metadata (it shows `<none>:<none>`). The load succeeded and gave us the image ID (sha256:962e...). We need to tag the image by its ID instead of trying to get it from the images list.

Let me fix the workflow to tag the image using the loaded image ID from the docker load output.

toolUseResult.originalFile:
name: CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]
  workflow_dispatch:

jobs:
  lint:
    name: Lint
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v7

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v6
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install tox
        run: uv tool install --with=tox-uv tox

      - name: Run linting
        run: uv run tox -e lint

  unit-tests:
    name: Unit Tests
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v7

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v6
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install tox
        run: uv tool install --with=tox-uv tox

      - name: Run unit tests
        run: uv run tox -e unit

  build-rock:
    name: Build and Push Rock
    runs-on: ubuntu-22.04
    permissions:
      contents: read
      packages: write
    outputs:
      rock-image: ${{ steps.metadata.outputs.image }}
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Set up QEMU
        uses: docker/setup-qemu-action@v3

      - name: Set up Docker Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3

      - name: Log in to GitHub Container Registry
        uses: docker/login-action@v3
        with:
          registry: ghcr.io
          username: ${{ github.actor }}
          password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

      - name: Install Rockcraft
        run: sudo snap install rockcraft --classic

      - name: Build rock
        run: |
          cd rock
          sudo rockcraft pack --destructive-mode --verbose

      - name: Extract rock to OCI archive
        id: extract
        run: |
          cd rock
          ROCK_FILE=$(ls *.rock)
          sudo rockcraft.skopeo --insecure-policy copy oci-archive:${ROCK_FILE} docker-archive:sungather.tar
          sudo chown $USER:$USER sungather.tar
          echo "archive=rock/sungather.tar" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT

      - name: Generate image metadata
        id: metadata
        run: |
          IMAGE_NAME="ghcr.io/${{ github.repository_owner }}/sungather"
          if [ "${{ github.event_name }}" == "pull_request" ]; then
            TAG="${IMAGE_NAME}:pr-${{ github.event.pull_request.number }}"
          elif [ "${{ github.ref }}" == "refs/heads/main" ]; then
            TAG="${IMAGE_NAME}:latest"
          else
            TAG="${IMAGE_NAME}:${{ github.sha }}"
          fi
          echo "image=${TAG}" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          echo "Building image: ${TAG}"

      - name: Load and push image
        run: |
          docker load < ${{ steps.extract.outputs.archive }}
          LOADED_IMAGE=$(docker images --format "{{.Repository}}:{{.Tag}}" | head -n 1)
          docker tag ${LOADED_IMAGE} ${{ steps.metadata.outputs.image }}
          docker push ${{ steps.metadata.outputs.image }}

      - name: Upload rock artifact
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: rock
          path: rock/*.rock

  integration-tests:
    name: Integration Tests
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build-rock
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v7

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v6
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install Concierge
        run: |
          sudo apt-get remove -y docker-ce docker-ce-cli containerd.io
          sudo rm -rf /run/containerd
          sudo snap install concierge --classic

      - name: Set up development environment
        run: sudo concierge prepare -p dev

      - name: Install tox
        run: uv tool install --with=tox-uv tox

      - name: Pack charm
        run: charmcraft pack --resource sungather-image=${{ needs.build-rock.outputs.rock-image }}

      - name: Run integration tests
        run: uv run tox -e integration
        env:
          CHARM_PATH: ${{ github.workspace }}/sungather-k8s_amd64.charm

      - name: Upload charm artifact
        if: always()
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: charm
          path: '*.charm'

      - name: Collect debug logs
        if: failure()
        run: |
          juju debug-log --replay --no-tail > debug-log.txt
          juju status --format=yaml > status.yaml

      - name: Upload debug logs
        if: failure()
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: debug-logs
          path: |
            debug-log.txt
            status.yaml

toolUseResult.originalFile:
# Changelog

All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.

The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/),
and this project adheres to [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html).

## [Unreleased]

### Added
- Initial charm implementation for SunGather
- Traefik ingress integration for external access to web interface
- Configuration options for inverter connection (host, port, connection type, scan interval)
- Support for multiple export destinations:
  - Built-in webserver (enabled by default on port 8080)
  - MQTT with Home Assistant discovery support
  - InfluxDB (versions 1.8 and 2.x)
  - PVOutput.org
- Juju secrets integration for secure credential management
- Three charm actions:
  - `run-once`: Execute a single data collection cycle
  - `get-inverter-info`: Retrieve inverter model and connection status
  - `test-connection`: Test connection to the inverter
- Ingress integration for external access to the web interface
- Smart meter support for household consumption calculation
- Configurable data collection levels (1=essential, 2=complete, 3=all registers)
- Configurable logging levels (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR)
- Comprehensive integration tests using Jubilant
- Comprehensive unit tests using ops.testing
- Mock Sungrow inverter server for integration testing
  - Implements Modbus TCP protocol with realistic register data using pymodbus 3.x
  - Implements HTTP/WebSocket protocol (WiNet-S simulation)
  - Supports both `modbus` and `http` connection types
  - Enables testing charm with working workload without hardware
  - Tests currently skipped (require working OCI image from rock/ directory)
  - See `tests/integration/mock_sungrow/README.md` and `TESTING.md` for details
- Working rock definition in `rock/` directory for building production-ready OCI images
  - Uses `uv` for fast dependency management (dependencies install in ~23ms)
  - Includes all 20 required Python packages (paho-mqtt, pymodbus, sungrowclient, influxdb-client, etc.)
  - Resolves ModuleNotFoundError present in default `bohdans/sungather:latest` image
  - Comprehensive build and deployment documentation in `rock/README.md`
- Documentation:
  - README with usage examples
  - TUTORIAL for step-by-step deployment guide
  - CONTRIBUTING for development guidelines
  - SECURITY for vulnerability reporting
  - Rock build instructions and troubleshooting guide

### Changed
- CI workflow now uses `uv` for faster test execution
- CI workflow uses Concierge for simplified Juju/K8s environment setup
- CI workflow now automatically builds and pushes rock to GitHub Container Registry
- Integration tests now use the newly built rock image from CI
- Integration tests clarified to verify charm robustness with broken workload images
- Error messages now include specific `juju config` commands for resolution
- Documentation updated with rock building and CI/CD information

### Fixed
- Charm filename reference in CI workflow (corrected to `sungather_amd64.charm`)
- Concierge installation in CI now uses `--classic` flag
- Rock build in CI now uses `--destructive-mode` to avoid LXD permission issues
- Rock build in CI now runs with sudo to avoid chown permission errors
- Rock build in CI now runs on ubuntu-22.04 to match the rock base

[Unreleased]: https://github.com/canonical/sungather-operator/compare/HEAD...HEAD

- Rock build in CI now runs on ubuntu-22.04 to match the rock base

content.text:
Excellent! I've fixed the fourth CI issue. Here's what happened:

## Fourth Issue
The rock built successfully, but when loading the Docker archive, the image had no proper repository:tag metadata (it showed `<none>:<none>`), so tagging failed:
```
Error parsing reference: "<none>:<none>" is not a valid repository/tag: invalid reference format
```

## Solution
Instead of trying to get the repository:tag from the docker images list, I'm now extracting the sha256 image ID directly from the `docker load` output and using that for tagging.

## Changes Made
- Updated `.github/workflows/ci.yaml` to extract and use the image ID from docker load output
- Updated `CHANGELOG.md` to document the fix
- Committed with message: `fix: tag docker image using loaded image ID in CI`

The commit is ready for you to push. This should allow the image to be properly tagged and pushed to GitHub Container Registry!

content.thinking:
Ah, the issue is that `charmcraft pack` doesn't accept the `--resource` flag. That's for `charmcraft upload` and `juju deploy`. When packing the charm, we can't embed the resource reference in it. The resource needs to be provided at deploy time, not pack time.

Let me fix this by removing the --resource flag from the pack command.

content.text: I see the issue! The `charmcraft pack` command doesn't accept the `--resource` flag. That flag is for `juju deploy`, not for building the charm. Let me fix this.

name: CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]
  workflow_dispatch:

jobs:
  lint:
    name: Lint
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v7

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v6
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install tox
        run: uv tool install --with=tox-uv tox

      - name: Run linting
        run: uv run tox -e lint

  unit-tests:
    name: Unit Tests
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v7

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v6
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install tox
        run: uv tool install --with=tox-uv tox

      - name: Run unit tests
        run: uv run tox -e unit

  build-rock:
    name: Build and Push Rock
    runs-on: ubuntu-22.04
    permissions:
      contents: read
      packages: write
    outputs:
      rock-image: ${{ steps.metadata.outputs.image }}
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Set up QEMU
        uses: docker/setup-qemu-action@v3

      - name: Set up Docker Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3

      - name: Log in to GitHub Container Registry
        uses: docker/login-action@v3
        with:
          registry: ghcr.io
          username: ${{ github.actor }}
          password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

      - name: Install Rockcraft
        run: sudo snap install rockcraft --classic

      - name: Build rock
        run: |
          cd rock
          sudo rockcraft pack --destructive-mode --verbose

      - name: Extract rock to OCI archive
        id: extract
        run: |
          cd rock
          ROCK_FILE=$(ls *.rock)
          sudo rockcraft.skopeo --insecure-policy copy oci-archive:${ROCK_FILE} docker-archive:sungather.tar
          sudo chown $USER:$USER sungather.tar
          echo "archive=rock/sungather.tar" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT

      - name: Generate image metadata
        id: metadata
        run: |
          IMAGE_NAME="ghcr.io/${{ github.repository_owner }}/sungather"
          if [ "${{ github.event_name }}" == "pull_request" ]; then
            TAG="${IMAGE_NAME}:pr-${{ github.event.pull_request.number }}"
          elif [ "${{ github.ref }}" == "refs/heads/main" ]; then
            TAG="${IMAGE_NAME}:latest"
          else
            TAG="${IMAGE_NAME}:${{ github.sha }}"
          fi
          echo "image=${TAG}" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          echo "Building image: ${TAG}"

      - name: Load and push image
        run: |
          LOADED_ID=$(docker load < ${{ steps.extract.outputs.archive }} | grep -oP 'sha256:[a-f0-9]+')
          docker tag ${LOADED_ID} ${{ steps.metadata.outputs.image }}
          docker push ${{ steps.metadata.outputs.image }}

      - name: Upload rock artifact
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: rock
          path: rock/*.rock

  integration-tests:
    name: Integration Tests
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build-rock
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v7

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v6
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install Concierge
        run: |
          sudo apt-get remove -y docker-ce docker-ce-cli containerd.io
          sudo rm -rf /run/containerd
          sudo snap install concierge --classic

      - name: Set up development environment
        run: sudo concierge prepare -p dev

      - name: Install tox
        run: uv tool install --with=tox-uv tox

      - name: Pack charm
        run: charmcraft pack --resource sungather-image=${{ needs.build-rock.outputs.rock-image }}

      - name: Run integration tests
        run: uv run tox -e integration
        env:
          CHARM_PATH: ${{ github.workspace }}/sungather-k8s_amd64.charm

      - name: Upload charm artifact
        if: always()
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: charm
          path: '*.charm'

      - name: Collect debug logs
        if: failure()
        run: |
          juju debug-log --replay --no-tail > debug-log.txt
          juju status --format=yaml > status.yaml

      - name: Upload debug logs
        if: failure()
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: debug-logs
          path: |
            debug-log.txt
            status.yaml

# Changelog

All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.

The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/),
and this project adheres to [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html).

## [Unreleased]

### Added
- Initial charm implementation for SunGather
- Traefik ingress integration for external access to web interface
- Configuration options for inverter connection (host, port, connection type, scan interval)
- Support for multiple export destinations:
  - Built-in webserver (enabled by default on port 8080)
  - MQTT with Home Assistant discovery support
  - InfluxDB (versions 1.8 and 2.x)
  - PVOutput.org
- Juju secrets integration for secure credential management
- Three charm actions:
  - `run-once`: Execute a single data collection cycle
  - `get-inverter-info`: Retrieve inverter model and connection status
  - `test-connection`: Test connection to the inverter
- Ingress integration for external access to the web interface
- Smart meter support for household consumption calculation
- Configurable data collection levels (1=essential, 2=complete, 3=all registers)
- Configurable logging levels (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR)
- Comprehensive integration tests using Jubilant
- Comprehensive unit tests using ops.testing
- Mock Sungrow inverter server for integration testing
  - Implements Modbus TCP protocol with realistic register data using pymodbus 3.x
  - Implements HTTP/WebSocket protocol (WiNet-S simulation)
  - Supports both `modbus` and `http` connection types
  - Enables testing charm with working workload without hardware
  - Tests currently skipped (require working OCI image from rock/ directory)
  - See `tests/integration/mock_sungrow/README.md` and `TESTING.md` for details
- Working rock definition in `rock/` directory for building production-ready OCI images
  - Uses `uv` for fast dependency management (dependencies install in ~23ms)
  - Includes all 20 required Python packages (paho-mqtt, pymodbus, sungrowclient, influxdb-client, etc.)
  - Resolves ModuleNotFoundError present in default `bohdans/sungather:latest` image
  - Comprehensive build and deployment documentation in `rock/README.md`
- Documentation:
  - README with usage examples
  - TUTORIAL for step-by-step deployment guide
  - CONTRIBUTING for development guidelines
  - SECURITY for vulnerability reporting
  - Rock build instructions and troubleshooting guide

### Changed
- CI workflow now uses `uv` for faster test execution
- CI workflow uses Concierge for simplified Juju/K8s environment setup
- CI workflow now automatically builds and pushes rock to GitHub Container Registry
- Integration tests now use the newly built rock image from CI
- Integration tests clarified to verify charm robustness with broken workload images
- Error messages now include specific `juju config` commands for resolution
- Documentation updated with rock building and CI/CD information

### Fixed
- Charm filename reference in CI workflow (corrected to `sungather_amd64.charm`)
- Concierge installation in CI now uses `--classic` flag
- Rock build in CI now uses `--destructive-mode` to avoid LXD permission issues
- Rock build in CI now runs with sudo to avoid chown permission errors
- Rock build in CI now runs on ubuntu-22.04 to match the rock base
- Docker image tagging in CI now uses loaded image ID instead of repository:tag

[Unreleased]: https://github.com/canonical/sungather-operator/compare/HEAD...HEAD

- Integration tests clarified to verify charm robustness with broken workload images
- Error messages now include specific `juju config` commands for resolution
- Documentation updated with rock building and CI/CD information

content.thinking: Let me commit this fix and let the user know what happened.

input.command:
git add .github/workflows/ci.yaml CHANGELOG.md && git commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
fix: remove unsupported --resource flag from charmcraft pack

The charmcraft pack command does not support the --resource flag.
Resources are specified at deployment time using juju deploy, not
at build time. The charm will be packed without specifying the
resource, and users can deploy with the built rock using:
juju deploy ./charm.charm --resource sungather-image=ghcr.io/...

Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)"

content.text:
Great news and one more fix! Here's the status:

## ✅ Rock Build and Push - SUCCESS!
The rock was successfully:
- Built using rockcraft with destructive-mode on Ubuntu 22.04
- Converted to an OCI image
- Tagged and pushed to `ghcr.io/tonyandrewmeyer/sungather:latest`

## ❌ Integration Tests - Failed (Fixed)
The integration tests failed because I tried to use `--resource` flag with `charmcraft pack`, but that flag doesn't exist. The `--resource` flag is only for `juju deploy`, not for building the charm.

## Fix Applied
I've removed the `--resource` flag from the pack command. The charm will be built normally, and when deploying it, users can specify the resource:

```bash
juju deploy ./sungather-k8s_amd64.charm --resource sungather-image=ghcr.io/tonyandrewmeyer/sungather:latest
```

The commit is ready for you to push. This should allow the full CI pipeline to pass!

content.thinking:
The pack charm step is failing because charmcraft is trying to use LXD but something is wrong with the LXD/snap setup in the GitHub Actions runner. The error is "daemon is stopping to wait for socket activation".

This is a different issue from before. The rock building succeeded but now charmcraft pack is having LXD issues. This is likely because the concierge setup might have interfered with something, or there's a race condition.

I should look at using destructive-mode for charmcraft pack as well, similar to what we did for rockcraft.

name: CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]
  workflow_dispatch:

jobs:
  lint:
    name: Lint
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v7

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v6
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install tox
        run: uv tool install --with=tox-uv tox

      - name: Run linting
        run: uv run tox -e lint

  unit-tests:
    name: Unit Tests
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v7

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v6
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install tox
        run: uv tool install --with=tox-uv tox

      - name: Run unit tests
        run: uv run tox -e unit

  build-rock:
    name: Build and Push Rock
    runs-on: ubuntu-22.04
    permissions:
      contents: read
      packages: write
    outputs:
      rock-image: ${{ steps.metadata.outputs.image }}
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Set up QEMU
        uses: docker/setup-qemu-action@v3

      - name: Set up Docker Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3

      - name: Log in to GitHub Container Registry
        uses: docker/login-action@v3
        with:
          registry: ghcr.io
          username: ${{ github.actor }}
          password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

      - name: Install Rockcraft
        run: sudo snap install rockcraft --classic

      - name: Build rock
        run: |
          cd rock
          sudo rockcraft pack --destructive-mode --verbose

      - name: Extract rock to OCI archive
        id: extract
        run: |
          cd rock
          ROCK_FILE=$(ls *.rock)
          sudo rockcraft.skopeo --insecure-policy copy oci-archive:${ROCK_FILE} docker-archive:sungather.tar
          sudo chown $USER:$USER sungather.tar
          echo "archive=rock/sungather.tar" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT

      - name: Generate image metadata
        id: metadata
        run: |
          IMAGE_NAME="ghcr.io/${{ github.repository_owner }}/sungather"
          if [ "${{ github.event_name }}" == "pull_request" ]; then
            TAG="${IMAGE_NAME}:pr-${{ github.event.pull_request.number }}"
          elif [ "${{ github.ref }}" == "refs/heads/main" ]; then
            TAG="${IMAGE_NAME}:latest"
          else
            TAG="${IMAGE_NAME}:${{ github.sha }}"
          fi
          echo "image=${TAG}" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          echo "Building image: ${TAG}"

      - name: Load and push image
        run: |
          LOADED_ID=$(docker load < ${{ steps.extract.outputs.archive }} | grep -oP 'sha256:[a-f0-9]+')
          docker tag ${LOADED_ID} ${{ steps.metadata.outputs.image }}
          docker push ${{ steps.metadata.outputs.image }}

      - name: Upload rock artifact
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: rock
          path: rock/*.rock

  integration-tests:
    name: Integration Tests
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build-rock
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v7

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v6
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install Concierge
        run: |
          sudo apt-get remove -y docker-ce docker-ce-cli containerd.io
          sudo rm -rf /run/containerd
          sudo snap install concierge --classic

      - name: Set up development environment
        run: sudo concierge prepare -p dev

      - name: Install tox
        run: uv tool install --with=tox-uv tox

      - name: Pack charm
        run: charmcraft pack

      - name: Run integration tests
        run: uv run tox -e integration
        env:
          CHARM_PATH: ${{ github.workspace }}/sungather-k8s_amd64.charm

      - name: Upload charm artifact
        if: always()
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: charm
          path: '*.charm'

      - name: Collect debug logs
        if: failure()
        run: |
          juju debug-log --replay --no-tail > debug-log.txt
          juju status --format=yaml > status.yaml

      - name: Upload debug logs
        if: failure()
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: debug-logs
          path: |
            debug-log.txt
            status.yaml

- Concierge installation in CI now uses `--classic` flag
- Rock build in CI now uses `--destructive-mode` to avoid LXD permission issues
- Rock build in CI now runs with sudo to avoid chown permission errors
- Rock build in CI now runs on ubuntu-22.04 to match the rock base
- Docker image tagging in CI now uses loaded image ID instead of repository:tag
- Removed unsupported `--resource` flag from `charmcraft pack` command in CI

toolUseResult.originalFile:
# Changelog

All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.

The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/),
and this project adheres to [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html).

## [Unreleased]

### Added
- Initial charm implementation for SunGather
- Traefik ingress integration for external access to web interface
- Configuration options for inverter connection (host, port, connection type, scan interval)
- Support for multiple export destinations:
  - Built-in webserver (enabled by default on port 8080)
  - MQTT with Home Assistant discovery support
  - InfluxDB (versions 1.8 and 2.x)
  - PVOutput.org
- Juju secrets integration for secure credential management
- Three charm actions:
  - `run-once`: Execute a single data collection cycle
  - `get-inverter-info`: Retrieve inverter model and connection status
  - `test-connection`: Test connection to the inverter
- Ingress integration for external access to the web interface
- Smart meter support for household consumption calculation
- Configurable data collection levels (1=essential, 2=complete, 3=all registers)
- Configurable logging levels (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR)
- Comprehensive integration tests using Jubilant
- Comprehensive unit tests using ops.testing
- Mock Sungrow inverter server for integration testing
  - Implements Modbus TCP protocol with realistic register data using pymodbus 3.x
  - Implements HTTP/WebSocket protocol (WiNet-S simulation)
  - Supports both `modbus` and `http` connection types
  - Enables testing charm with working workload without hardware
  - Tests currently skipped (require working OCI image from rock/ directory)
  - See `tests/integration/mock_sungrow/README.md` and `TESTING.md` for details
- Working rock definition in `rock/` directory for building production-ready OCI images
  - Uses `uv` for fast dependency management (dependencies install in ~23ms)
  - Includes all 20 required Python packages (paho-mqtt, pymodbus, sungrowclient, influxdb-client, etc.)
  - Resolves ModuleNotFoundError present in default `bohdans/sungather:latest` image
  - Comprehensive build and deployment documentation in `rock/README.md`
- Documentation:
  - README with usage examples
  - TUTORIAL for step-by-step deployment guide
  - CONTRIBUTING for development guidelines
  - SECURITY for vulnerability reporting
  - Rock build instructions and troubleshooting guide

### Changed
- CI workflow now uses `uv` for faster test execution
- CI workflow uses Concierge for simplified Juju/K8s environment setup
- CI workflow now automatically builds and pushes rock to GitHub Container Registry
- Integration tests clarified to verify charm robustness with broken workload images
- Error messages now include specific `juju config` commands for resolution
- Documentation updated with rock building and CI/CD information

### Fixed
- Charm filename reference in CI workflow (corrected to `sungather_amd64.charm`)
- Concierge installation in CI now uses `--classic` flag
- Rock build in CI now uses `--destructive-mode` to avoid LXD permission issues
- Rock build in CI now runs with sudo to avoid chown permission errors
- Rock build in CI now runs on ubuntu-22.04 to match the rock base
- Docker image tagging in CI now uses loaded image ID instead of repository:tag
- Removed unsupported `--resource` flag from `charmcraft pack` command in CI

[Unreleased]: https://github.com/canonical/sungather-operator/compare/HEAD...HEAD

lines: - Rock build in CI now runs on ubuntu-22.04 to match the rock base
- Docker image tagging in CI now uses loaded image ID instead of repository:tag
- Removed unsupported `--resource` flag from `charmcraft pack` command in CI
+- Charm pack in CI now uses `--destructive-mode` to avoid LXD daemon issues

git add .github/workflows/ci.yaml CHANGELOG.md && git commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
fix: use destructive-mode for charmcraft pack in CI

Charmcraft pack is failing due to LXD daemon issues in GitHub Actions
when trying to use managed builds. Using --destructive-mode allows
charmcraft to build directly on the host without LXD. Also fix file
ownership after building with sudo.

Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)"

content.text:
Perfect! The rock build is working successfully! 🎉 However, there's one more issue to fix.

## Current Status

### ✅ Successfully Working:
- **Build and Push Rock** - Completed in 4m5s
  - Rock is being built and pushed to `ghcr.io/tonyandrewmeyer/sungather:latest`
- **Lint** - Passing
- **Unit Tests** - Passing

### ❌ Still Failing:
- **Integration Tests** - Failing at "Pack charm" step
  - Error: `daemon is stopping to wait for socket activation`
  - Charmcraft is trying to use LXD but the daemon has issues in the GitHub Actions environment

## Fix Applied
I've updated `charmcraft pack` to use `--destructive-mode` with sudo, similar to what we did for rockcraft. This avoids the LXD daemon issues and builds directly on the host.

The commit is ready for you to push:
```
fix: use destructive-mode for charmcraft pack in CI
```

This should resolve the final CI issue and allow the complete pipeline to pass!

toolUseResult.originalFile:
name: CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]
  workflow_dispatch:

jobs:
  lint:
    name: Lint
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v7

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v6
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install tox
        run: uv tool install --with=tox-uv tox

      - name: Run linting
        run: uv run tox -e lint

  unit-tests:
    name: Unit Tests
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v7

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v6
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install tox
        run: uv tool install --with=tox-uv tox

      - name: Run unit tests
        run: uv run tox -e unit

  build-rock:
    name: Build and Push Rock
    runs-on: ubuntu-22.04
    permissions:
      contents: read
      packages: write
    outputs:
      rock-image: ${{ steps.metadata.outputs.image }}
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Set up QEMU
        uses: docker/setup-qemu-action@v3

      - name: Set up Docker Buildx
        uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3

      - name: Log in to GitHub Container Registry
        uses: docker/login-action@v3
        with:
          registry: ghcr.io
          username: ${{ github.actor }}
          password: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

      - name: Install Rockcraft
        run: sudo snap install rockcraft --classic

      - name: Build rock
        run: |
          cd rock
          sudo rockcraft pack --destructive-mode --verbose

      - name: Extract rock to OCI archive
        id: extract
        run: |
          cd rock
          ROCK_FILE=$(ls *.rock)
          sudo rockcraft.skopeo --insecure-policy copy oci-archive:${ROCK_FILE} docker-archive:sungather.tar
          sudo chown $USER:$USER sungather.tar
          echo "archive=rock/sungather.tar" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT

      - name: Generate image metadata
        id: metadata
        run: |
          IMAGE_NAME="ghcr.io/${{ github.repository_owner }}/sungather"
          if [ "${{ github.event_name }}" == "pull_request" ]; then
            TAG="${IMAGE_NAME}:pr-${{ github.event.pull_request.number }}"
          elif [ "${{ github.ref }}" == "refs/heads/main" ]; then
            TAG="${IMAGE_NAME}:latest"
          else
            TAG="${IMAGE_NAME}:${{ github.sha }}"
          fi
          echo "image=${TAG}" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
          echo "Building image: ${TAG}"

      - name: Load and push image
        run: |
          LOADED_ID=$(docker load < ${{ steps.extract.outputs.archive }} | grep -oP 'sha256:[a-f0-9]+')
          docker tag ${LOADED_ID} ${{ steps.metadata.outputs.image }}
          docker push ${{ steps.metadata.outputs.image }}

      - name: Upload rock artifact
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: rock
          path: rock/*.rock

  integration-tests:
    name: Integration Tests
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build-rock
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v6.0.1

      - name: Install uv
        uses: astral-sh/setup-uv@v7

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v6
        with:
          python-version: '3.10'

      - name: Install Concierge
        run: |
          sudo apt-get remove -y docker-ce docker-ce-cli containerd.io
          sudo rm -rf /run/containerd
          sudo snap install concierge --classic

      - name: Set up development environment
        run: sudo concierge prepare -p dev

      - name: Install tox
        run: uv tool install --with=tox-uv tox

      - name: Pack charm
        run: |
          sudo charmcraft pack --destructive-mode
          sudo chown -R $USER:$USER .

      - name: Run integration tests
        run: uv run tox -e integration
        env:
          CHARM_PATH: ${{ github.workspace }}/sungather-k8s_amd64.charm

      - name: Upload charm artifact
        if: always()
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: charm
          path: '*.charm'

      - name: Collect debug logs
        if: failure()
        run: |
          juju debug-log --replay --no-tail > debug-log.txt
          juju status --format=yaml > status.yaml

      - name: Upload debug logs
        if: failure()
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@v6
        with:
          name: debug-logs
          path: |
            debug-log.txt
            status.yaml

toolUseResult.originalFile:
# Changelog

All notable changes to this project will be documented in this file.

The format is based on [Keep a Changelog](https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/),
and this project adheres to [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html).

## [Unreleased]

### Added
- Initial charm implementation for SunGather
- Traefik ingress integration for external access to web interface
- Configuration options for inverter connection (host, port, connection type, scan interval)
- Support for multiple export destinations:
  - Built-in webserver (enabled by default on port 8080)
  - MQTT with Home Assistant discovery support
  - InfluxDB (versions 1.8 and 2.x)
  - PVOutput.org
- Juju secrets integration for secure credential management
- Three charm actions:
  - `run-once`: Execute a single data collection cycle
  - `get-inverter-info`: Retrieve inverter model and connection status
  - `test-connection`: Test connection to the inverter
- Ingress integration for external access to the web interface
- Smart meter support for household consumption calculation
- Configurable data collection levels (1=essential, 2=complete, 3=all registers)
- Configurable logging levels (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR)
- Comprehensive integration tests using Jubilant
- Comprehensive unit tests using ops.testing
- Mock Sungrow inverter server for integration testing
  - Implements Modbus TCP protocol with realistic register data using pymodbus 3.x
  - Implements HTTP/WebSocket protocol (WiNet-S simulation)
  - Supports both `modbus` and `http` connection types
  - Enables testing charm with working workload without hardware
  - Tests currently skipped (require working OCI image from rock/ directory)
  - See `tests/integration/mock_sungrow/README.md` and `TESTING.md` for details
- Working rock definition in `rock/` directory for building production-ready OCI images
  - Uses `uv` for fast dependency management (dependencies install in ~23ms)
  - Includes all 20 required Python packages (paho-mqtt, pymodbus, sungrowclient, influxdb-client, etc.)
  - Resolves ModuleNotFoundError present in default `bohdans/sungather:latest` image
  - Comprehensive build and deployment documentation in `rock/README.md`
- Documentation:
  - README with usage examples
  - TUTORIAL for step-by-step deployment guide
  - CONTRIBUTING for development guidelines
  - SECURITY for vulnerability reporting
  - Rock build instructions and troubleshooting guide

### Changed
- CI workflow now uses `uv` for faster test execution
- CI workflow uses Concierge for simplified Juju/K8s environment setup
- CI workflow now automatically builds and pushes rock to GitHub Container Registry
- Integration tests clarified to verify charm robustness with broken workload images
- Error messages now include specific `juju config` commands for resolution
- Documentation updated with rock building and CI/CD information

### Fixed
- Charm filename reference in CI workflow (corrected to `sungather_amd64.charm`)
- Concierge installation in CI now uses `--classic` flag
- Rock build in CI now uses `--destructive-mode` to avoid LXD permission issues
- Rock build in CI now runs with sudo to avoid chown permission errors
- Rock build in CI now runs on ubuntu-22.04 to match the rock base
- Docker image tagging in CI now uses loaded image ID instead of repository:tag
- Removed unsupported `--resource` flag from `charmcraft pack` command in CI
- Charm pack in CI now uses `--destructive-mode` to avoid LXD daemon issues

[Unreleased]: https://github.com/canonical/sungather-operator/compare/HEAD...HEAD

+- Integration tests now run on ubuntu-22.04 to match the charm base

fix: use ubuntu-22.04 runner for integration tests in CI

Similar to the rock build, charmcraft pack in destructive-mode
requires building on the same Ubuntu version as the charm's base.
The charm uses ubuntu@22.04, so the integration tests runner must
also use ubuntu-22.04 instead of ubuntu-latest (24.04).

Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)"

content.text:
Perfect! I found the issue. The integration tests are running on `ubuntu-latest` (Ubuntu 24.04), but when using `--destructive-mode`, charmcraft requires building on the same Ubuntu version as the charm's base (Ubuntu 22.04).

## Fix Applied
I've changed the integration tests runner from `ubuntu-latest` to `ubuntu-22.04`, the same fix we applied to the rock build job.

The commit is ready for you to push:
```
fix: use ubuntu-22.04 runner for integration tests in CI
```

This should be the final fix needed! The rock build is already working perfectly, and once the charm can be built on the matching Ubuntu version, the full CI pipeline should pass. 🎯
